string-array.name: ssid
string-array.item: Service Set Identifier. Your network\'s name.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_set_(802.11_network)#SSID

string-array.name: bssid
string-array.item: Basic Service Set Identifier. A 48-bit label abiding by MAC-48 conventions which identifies your devices basic service set.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_set_(802.11_network)#BSSID

string-array.name: ipv4
string-array.item: Internet Protocol Address, serving the two main purposes of identifying the network interface of your device and providing it\'s location within the network, thereby making it addressable. The IPv4 representation corresponds to a 32-bit number. The displayed address is your internal one, meaning that it\'s only visible from within your network.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IP_address

string-array.name: ipv6_local
string-array.item: Internet Protocol Address, serving the two main purposes of identifying the network interface of your device and providing it\'s location within the network, thereby making it addressable. The IPv6 representation corresponds to a 128-bit number. This is the local IPv6 address, meaning that it\'s only visible from within your network.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IP_address

string-array.name: ipv6_public_1
string-array.item: Internet Protocol Address, serving the two main purposes of identifying the network interface of your device and providing it\'s location within the network, thereby making it addressable. The IPv6 representation corresponds to a 128-bit number. This is one of the two public IPv6 addresses, Android devices are typically assigned with. Of those two addresses, one comes from the Stateless Address Autoconfiguration (SLAAC) mechanism - meaning that it will always be the same - whereas the other one is a privacy variant, that changes every few hours.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IP_address

string-array.name: ipv6_public_2
string-array.item: Internet Protocol Address, serving the two main purposes of identifying the network interface of your device and providing it\'s location within the network, thereby making it addressable. The IPv6 representation corresponds to a 128-bit number. This is one of the two public IPv6 addresses, Android devices are typically assigned with. Of those two addresses, one comes from the Stateless Address Autoconfiguration (SLAAC) mechanism - meaning that it will always be the same - whereas the other one is a privacy variant, that changes every few hours.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IP_address

string-array.name: frequency
string-array.item: The radio frequency band employed for WiFi signal transmission, following the IEEE 802.11 technical standards. Bands for use in WiFi communication provided by IEEE 802.11 lie at 900 MHz, 2.4 GHz, 3.6 GHz, 4.9 GHz, 5 GHz, 5.9 GHz, 6 GHz and 60 GHz. Bands are divided into several distinct channels.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_WLAN_channels

string-array.name: channel
string-array.item: The sub frequencies which the main frequency bands are divided into, and via which WiFi communication takes place. As per the IEEE 802.11 standard, channels are numbered at 5 MHz spacing within a band (except in the 60 GHz band, where they are 2.16 GHz apart), where the number corresponds to the centre frequency of the channel. Although channels are numbered at 5 MHz spacing, transmitters generally occupy at least 20 MHz, and standards allow for channels to be bonded together to form wider channels for faster throughput.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_WLAN_channels

string-array.name: link_speed
string-array.item: The theoretical data transmission max speed between your device and the router.

string-array.name: gateway
string-array.item: A Gateway is a device uniting the functionality of a modem, i.e., communicating with your ISP (Internet Service Provider), and a router, i.e., translating the data received by the modem and distributing it as WiFi signal to the client devices being present in the network.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gateway_(telecommunications)#Network_gateway

string-array.name: dns
string-array.item: Domain Name System. Associates domain names with various types of information, acting as a database. Most notably, it translates domain names to their underlying IP addresses, needed for locating and communicating with them.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_Name_System

string-array.name: dhcp
string-array.item: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol. A service which automatically assigns IP addresses and other network parameters to devices connected to a network.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_Host_Configuration_Protocol

string-array.name: netmask
string-array.item: Also referred to as subnet mask. A bitmask determining the subnetwork within which the DHCP may operate.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subnetwork
